chunks.en: Where are the goals and endpoints for tech people?

When I went home for the Chinese New Year, I had the opportunity to communicate with relatives and friends in other industries. I found that age anxiety is generally not as severe as in the IT industry, and people live more freely and don't even talk about career planning.

But when I return to the big city, I am naturally swept up in a wave of anxiety.
My colleagues around me have also had a lot of ups and downs in the past two years. Some graduate school colleagues are even selling houses because they are getting older.

Where is the goal of our industry? When I first joined the industry, I was very excited and wanted to become a well-known tech person, but I was gradually slapped in the face by reality.

If 35 is a threshold, what is the point of desperately pushing technology now? What are everyone's visions for the future?
Just making a living. Boasting in interviews is just boasting. You can deceive others, but don't deceive yourself.
Because other people take it one year at a time, and see how the New Year goes when the time comes.
For example, the goal of most farmers is to raise their children and get enough fifteen years of social security.
You are anxious because you want more than them.
This is not our problem, but the problem brought about by China's pursuit of 'high-speed development' for so many years, regardless of 'low social health'.
Save money/accumulate technology and go abroad. There are many places to go, such as Japan/Singapore/European countries/Australia/America.
Although going there does not mean that all problems will disappear, the overall 'health' of social development there is much higher than in China.

After settling down, the overall living conditions will be much better than in China. What's more, children will no longer be affected by China's 'development disease' in the future, and can grow up much happier. This may be the life goal of many people.

chunks.en: First of all, understand that you don't have much technology. There are only a few people in the world who can truly be called technical. The others are just making a living by selling their strength. Just because you are working with computers doesn't mean you are related to technology. Many people think that pushing technology is nothing more than reading more documents and knowing a few more APIs. What kind of technology is this?
Security guard, Meituan, Didi, or go to the manufacturing industry to do IT?
Personally, I think it is difficult for IT people to have any entrepreneurial directions except for making small games on Steam.
@dmanbu I feel this path is not easy to take either.
@fliter There are two types of entrepreneurship. One is to benefit from policies, that is, to have someone at the top.
But this situation is difficult for ordinary programmers without network resources.
The other is to push technology and steal other people's jobs.
Now is the era of APP stock, without solid technology, you may not be able to steal from others.
Some old programmers write code very well and can survive in the competition. They all have something special.
Because you have higher requirements for yourself? Do you have greater hope for yourself?

People who graduated from junior high school or high school find a factory to work in their hometown, buy a house when they should, get married when they should, and no one in the family thinks that buying a house is a big risk, what to do if they lose their job, what to do if they have children and repeat their lives.
I think our expectations are higher. Maybe we went to university and graduate school, so naturally we have higher expectations for our future.

There are always factories in my hometown. As long as my hands and feet are healthy, there will always be people who want us. In the IT industry, work when you have a shift, and go home when you don't. As long as you can accept such a future, life is actually very good.
Now I am forcing myself to lower my expectations for the future. At worst, I will not get married or have children. At worst, I will just go home and work.
@hongyexiaoqing Haozi is a very good technician, but it is very ironic that he died so young. Obviously, Haozi's quality of life is not very good.
So, is the technical staff route he advocates really correct?
If it is correct, why did he die so early?
Have you communicated with people in other industries when you "returned to the big city"?
It is taboo to compare without controlling variables. Think of one thing at a time.
just do it
@cong Push stones up the mountain every day like Sisyphus
Similarly, learning is not just going to class, and technology is not just going to work. It is best to discuss them separately.
For me, technology has no end, but it is best not to work.
Look at the various public accounts selling courses now, teaching others to 'get high salaries'. Aren't they the so-called well-known technical people in the eyes of laymen?
The essence of pushing technology is actually just a way to please the boss. Whether it is useful or not, as long as the boss is happy, this is the same in many industries.
Most people are just making a living. Of course, I am just expressing what I know about ordinary people. Big shots are not included in this scope.

I personally plan to wait until I am 25-27 and go abroad to study for a graduate degree according to my amateur hobbies. I already have many senior students I know who have gone to Japan to study for a graduate degree in music (CS major but learned a certain instrument since elementary school, and quit their jobs directly when they didn't want to do it anymore).
They are happy every day and can't see any anxiety.
Looking at the music industry in Japan, basically people start to achieve success between the ages of 30 and 50.
Already ran away...
Not working
My goal is to be able to easily find a job, and not have to gap for a few months after losing my job...
